entry.title: SAP Integration Suite Quickstart: TPM, Integration Advisor, and AS2 Integrationâ€”Your Practical Guide
entry.content:
My Practical Kickstart with SAP Integration Suite: TPM & Integration Advisor

When I first started working with SAP Integration Suite, I quickly realized how overwhelming the documentation and theory could be. My goal with this series is to share the exact steps and lessons I learned, so you can get hands-on with message-based integration without getting lost in the weeds.

Why This Series Exists?

In my day-to-day projects, Iâ€™ve needed to:

  • Onboard new trading partners using TPM
  • Build secure message flows with AS2 adapters
  • Transform EDI documents using Integration Advisor

I noticed that while SAP provides  set of tools, the real challenge is connecting the dots between theory and practical implementation. Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ll focus on real steps you can follow, based on what actually worked for me in client environments.

What Youâ€™ll Get from My Approach

1. End-to-end setup:  Iâ€™ll walk you through setting up SAP Integration Suite from scratch, including the initial login, configuring adapters, and deploying your first integration flow.

2. Hands-on with security:  Iâ€™ve spent a lot of time fine-tuning AS2 Receiver and Sender Adapters, setting up API Proxies, and using Groovy scripts for OAuth 2.0, decryption, and signature validation. Iâ€™ll share the scripts and configuration tips that saved me hours.

3. Integration Advisor in action:  Iâ€™ll show you how I used Integration Advisor to generate Mapping Guidelines (MIG) and Mapping Artifacts (MAG), and how the EDI Converter and MIG Schema simplified complex message transformations.

4. Reliable B2B messaging:  Iâ€™ll cover how I handled asynchronous Message Disposition Notifications (MDN) to ensure message delivery and compliance.

Hereâ€™s the sequence I found most logical when I set up my last B2B integration project:

Introduction:  Iâ€™ll start with a solution architecture diagram and a checklist of prerequisites, based on what tripped me up initially.

AS2 Receiver Adapter:  Iâ€™ll share my configuration steps and troubleshooting notes.

API Proxy Setup:  How I built a secure API layer, including lessons learned from failed attempts.

AS2 Sender Setup:  Advanced security with Groovy scriptingâ€”my favorite snippets included.

Integration Advisor Deep Dive:  Creating and using MIGs and MAGs, with screenshots from my own environment.

EDI Converter & MIG Schema:  How I handled tricky message transformations.

Async MDN Handling:  My approach to making integration flows robust and reliable.

Solution Architecture Diagram

 

Why Follow This Series?

No fluff:  Everything here comes from actual project work , no theory for theoryâ€™s sake.

Visual learning:  Iâ€™ll include diagrams and screenshots from my own SAP BTP environment, not just generic images.

Community-driven:  If you run into issues or want me to cover a specific scenario, comment below. Iâ€™m happy to share what Iâ€™ve learned or dig into new challenges.

Prerequisites

Youâ€™ll need:

  • An SAP BTP sub-account
  • A running Integration Suite service instance
  • Integration Advisor subscription
  • Basic integration and EDI knowledge
  • Access to a dev environment (I use SAP Cloud Integration and Business Application Studio)

Letâ€™s Dive In

This isnâ€™t just another technical blog itâ€™s a collection of hard-won lessons from my journey with SAP Integration Suite. In the next post, Iâ€™ll walk you through configuring the AS2 Receiver Adapter for secure, reliable message flows, including the pitfalls I encountered and how I solved them.

If you find these guides helpful, please give a thumbs up or leave a comment with your integration wish-list. Your feedback shapes what I write next.

â€Œâ€Œ Disclaimer:  All views here are my own, based on real project experience. Always validate configurations in your own environment.

entry.title: Re: Time-based revenue recognition in the public cloud
entry.content:
Hi Naveen, 

Thank you for your question. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition, this topic needs to be approached from a slightly different perspective. The system is designed around integrated, end-to-end business processes, so itâ€™s important to first define your operational scenario.

Common use cases include:

  • Project-based services
  • Service contracts
  • Integration with SAP Subscription Billing

For service contracts, you typically create a service contract (which can also originate from an external system) with an associated billing plan. Revenue can then be distributed across the billing plan amounts and the relevant settlement periods.

The most straightforward approach for revenue recognition in this context is to leverage the following scope items:

  • 3MO â€“ Service Contract Management
  • 3M3, 3M4/3M5 â€“ Event-Based Revenue Recognition for Service

If your requirements include more advanced capabilitiesâ€”such as bundling or revenue allocationâ€”you can enhance the setup above using contract-based revenue recognition via scope items 3KK or 3VS. This is often referred to as Universal Revenue Recognition, as it combines the strengths of both EBRR (Event-Based Revenue Recognition) and CBRR (Contract-Based Revenue Recognition).

You can find more detailed guidance in the SAP Help Portal (here) or in the following blog post: [here]

Regards, 

Volkmar Zahn

Product Management S/4HANA Finance

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide: Secure File Exchange with AS2 Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration
entry.content:
Sending and Receiving with AS2

Ready for a quick, hands-on story about sending files safely between companies? In this part, weâ€™ll walk through how to set up the AS2 protocolâ€”a popular way to send important documents online, keeping them private and making sure they arrive as intended.

Youâ€™ll learn how to:

  • Set up your system to send and receive files using AS2
  • Turn on security features to keep your files safe while they travel
  • Get a special receipt (called an MDN) every time a file is delivered, so you know it made it safely
  • Handle big batches of files and make sure each one is tracked properly

All of this is designed so you can follow along in just 10â€“15 minutesâ€”no fuss, no confusion. By the end, youâ€™ll have a working setup that connects smoothly with the tools weâ€™ll cover next.

In this blog I am using two tenants One as sender Adapter [who is receiving the Data]and one as |Receiver Adapter [who is sending the Data].

Workflow Mechanism

Tenant 1: Sender Adapter Configuration

 

Feature

Details

Authentication 1

Role-Based via Load Balancer with ESB Messaging role

Decryption

Use Receiver's Certificate

Signing

Use own Keypair Name Algorithm: e.g., SHA256withRSA

MDN (Message Disposition Notification)

Asynchronous MDN - Use same certificate used in Decryption - Authentication: Basic Auth or Client Certificate (depends on Tenant 2 setup) - Triggered by Asynchronous iFlow from Tenant 2

 

Tenant 2: Receiver Adapter Configuration

 

Feature

Details

Authentication

Basic Auth or Client Certificate - Use Client ID/Secret or PFX file received from Sender

Encryption

- Create and configure a Key Pair - Specify keypair name in Encryption Section - Use the same algorithm as the keypair

Signing

- Upload and configure the Senderâ€™s Certificate

MDN Synchronous

- Use Senderâ€™s certificate for signing

MDN Asynchronous

- No authentication required

 

Tenant 2: Asynchronous Flow (for MDN callback)

 

Feature

Details

Authorization

- Role-based access - Forward the PFX file to Tenant 1 (Sender) - Used to sign MDN or decrypt incoming AS2 messages

AS2 sender (Receiving data) Configurations

Step 1: Create an I Flow 

  • Log in to SAP Cloud Integration (CPI)
  • Open your CPI tenant. 
  • Go toâ€¯Design. 
  • Create a New Integration Flow: 
  • Click onâ€¯Artifactsâ€¯under your desired package. 
  • Clickâ€¯Addâ€¯>â€¯Integration Flow. 
  • Provide aâ€¯Nameâ€¯andâ€¯Description. 
  • Clickâ€¯OK. 

Step 2: Add Sender and Start Message 

  • Add Sender: 
  • In the IFlow canvas, drag theâ€¯Senderâ€¯element from the palette to the left side of the flow. 
  • Configure Sender with AS2 Adapter 
  • Click on theâ€¯Senderâ€¯element. 
  • Connect Sender to Start Message 
  • In theâ€¯Adapter Typeâ€¯dropdown, selectâ€¯AS2. 
  • Click theâ€¯pencil/editâ€¯icon to modify the AS2 adapter settings 

Step 3: In the connection tab of AS2 Adapter 

Address: 

  • This is the endpoint path to which the AS2 messages will be sent. 
  • Use a unique and descriptive path (e.g., /as2/receiver-partner). 
  • Ensure it is consistent with your partner configuration. 

Authorization: 

  • You need to specify the authorization type for accessing the AS2 endpoint. 
  • Typically, this is "User Role". 

User Role: 

  • The user role assigned here must have access rights to call or expose the AS2 endpoint. 
  • Example: ESBMessaging.send, AS2InboundUser, or any custom role with proper permissions. 

 

  • This the role that I was being used in the AS2 Endpoint creation iflow. If you would like to create a new role. Create in the Manage Security Material > User Roles and you can assign the role in the Integration flow service key instance so that this service key instance credentials can be used for authentication.

 

I have assigned role in the Integration flow Instance (DEV) and Updated the Instance.

I have assigned role in the Integration flow Instance (DEV) and Updated the Instance.

Step 4: In the processing Tab of AS2 Adapter 

PARTNER ID RESOLUTION 

Source: Authorized User 

  • This means the AS2 partner is determined based on the authenticated user calling the endpoint. 
  • The user must be mapped to a partner AS2 ID in your system. 

EXPECTED MESSAGES 

 These fields define criteria to filter and validate inbound AS2 messages: 

Message ID Left Part / Right Part: 

  • Typically used to validate a pattern in the AS2 message ID. 
  • Default is 0 which means no filtering is applied.

Partner AS2 ID: 

  • Expected AS2 identifier of the partner. 
  • 0 means no specific partner filtering. 

Own AS2 ID: 

  • Your tenant's AS2 ID. Used to verify the To: AS2 header. 
  • If set to 0, it's not enforced. 

Message Subject: 

  • Can be used to filter messages based on the subject header. 
  • 0 means subject is not checked. 

Number of Concurrent Processes: 

  • Controls parallel processing of incoming messages. 
  • Set to 1 in screenshot â€” means single-threaded processing for this endpoint. 

MESSAGE SETTINGS 

Mandatory File Name: 

  • If enabled, the AS2 message must include a filename. 
  • Useful for systems relying on filename-based routing. 

Duplicate Message ID: 

  • If enabled, it checks for duplicate AS2 message IDs and avoids processing them again. 
  • Prevents reprocessing of already received messages. 

Duplicate File Name: 

  • Checks for duplicate file names in incoming messages. 

Step 5: Configuration of Security tab in AS2 Adapter: 

MESSAGE DECRYPTION 

Decryption Configuration Type: Channel Configuration 

  • This means the decryption settings are configured directly in the adapter, not inherited from integration flow settings. 

Decrypt Message: (Checked) 

  • This indicates the incoming AS2 message is expected to be encrypted. 
  • CPI will decrypt it using the specified private key. 

Private Key Alias: 

  • This is the alias of the private key created in the Keystore of your tenant. 
  • CPI uses this private key to decrypt the AS2 message. 
  • You have to create the Keypair in the keystore (with alias like as2_decryption_key).   After Creating it, we have to download the certificate of the keypair which we have created.
  • Ensure the certificate is sent to the person who is encrypting data.

SIGNATURE VERIFICATION 

Verify Signature: Not Required 

  • Means the inbound AS2 message is not expected to be signed. 
  • CPI will not verify the digital signature of the message. 

Required: TRUSTED CERTIFICATE 

  • Enforces signature verification. 
  • Verifies if signature is present but doesnâ€™t fail if it's missing. 
  • Add the Certificate in the keystore which received from the receiver with the name and mention it in the public key alias  

Required: TRUSTED ROOT CERTIFICATE  

  • For this get the root certificate from the Receiver and upload in the Keystore with alias name and mention in the Iflow.

Step 6: Configuration of MDN tab in AS2 Adapter: 

Private Key Alias for Signature:

  • Used to sign the MDN (Message Disposition Notification).
  • Ensure the alias exists in Keystore. (This is the name of the keypair that you have used in the decryption process)

Signature Encoding:

  • Format of the MDN signature.
  • Options: binary or base64. [ Better to keep it required as we have Provide private key]

Propagate MDN Details to Exchange:

  • Sends MDN info (like disposition, timestamp) to integration flow.
  • Optional â€“ enable if needed by downstream logic. [Better to keep it required]

Negative MDN on Processing Failures:

  • Sends a negative MDN if message processing fails.
  • Useful for notifying partners about issues.

Asynchronous MDN Connection Settings:

Proxy Type:

  • Typically set to Internet.

Authentication:

  • Method to authenticate async MDN responses.
  • Usually None unless required by proxy.

Timeout (in ms):

  • Wait time for async MDN.
  • Example: 300000 ms = 5 minutes.

 

Feature/Aspect

Synchronous MDN (AS2)

Asynchronous MDN (AS2)

MDN Handling

MDN (receipt) is generated and attached to the log immediately when the AS2 endpoint is hit, regardless of payload correctness.

MDN response is delayed; the system waits to send the MDN to another AS2 endpoint (possibly on a different tenant).

Endpoint

MDN returned to sender in the same HTTP session as the original message.

MDN sent to a different AS2 endpoint (may be on another tenant), not in the same session.

Authentication

Uses the sender's own credentials or local settings.

Requires the PFX file (certificate) of the target AS2 endpointâ€™s tenant for authentication.

Use Case

Immediate acknowledgment, simple integration, and logging.

Flexible routing, multi-tenant or cross-system integrations, delayed or custom processing.

Step 7: Configuration of Delivery Assurance tab in AS2 Adapter: 

Quality of Service:

  • Set to Exactly Once â€“ ensures no duplicate message processing.

Retry Interval (in min):

  • Initial retry delay.
  • Example: 1 min before first retry.

Exponential Backoff:

  • Retries wait longer after each failure (e.g., 1 â†’ 2 â†’ 4 min).

Maximum Retry Interval (in min):

  • Max delay between retries.
  • Example: 60 min.

Dead-Letter Queue:

  • Failed messages go to DLQ after max retries â€“ helps in error analysis.

Encrypt Message During Persistence:

  • Ensures messages are encrypted when stored â€“ enhances security.

Step 8: Configuration of Conditions tab in AS2 Adapter: 

Body Size (in MB):

  • Max size for the main AS2 message body.
  • Example: 40 MB
  • Set based on expected payload size.
  • Helps avoid memory overload.

Attachments Size (in MB):

  • Max total size for all attachments.
  • Example: 100 MB
  • Set based on typical file sizes (e.g., PDFs, XML).
  • Prevents oversized message issues.

Note the As2 Endpoint after it gets deployed stage.

AS2 Receiver Adapter (Sending Request with payload)

  1. Create a new Iflow in the same tenant or any other different tenant (Would be best if it is another tenant)
  2. Design the iflow as specified in the above manner with all the necessary pallet functions

  • In the Connection tab. Give the as2 endpoint that you have from the sender adapter.
  • Select the authentication to be basic and paste the credential name from the security material.

Now for the basic authentication. Get the Client id and client secret from the Sender Adapter tenant which can be found in integration flow plan service key.

  • After you have gained the client id and client secret. Go to Monitor>Manage Security material> Security Material
  • Select Create>User Credentials
  • Paste the Client id in the user section and the client secret in password and repeat password with a proper naming convention.

  • In the processing tab. Give a proper File name for transferring and fill all the sections that you have done in the sender adapter iflow with the same ones.
  • Mention the content type to be application/edi-x12 as we are transferring the payload from EDI format.

In the Security Tab.

  • Select the Compress message for reducing the size of the payload you need to send.
  • For Signing Message, you need to create Keypair in the Keystore>Monitor tab with the alias name AS2_signing.
  • Give the alias name in private key alias
  • You have to download the certificate from the keypair (which you have created just now for signing) and give it to the sender in the other tenant.
  • For Encrypting the Message, you need to get the certificate from the person who is decrypting, then you have to upload certificate in the keystore > Monitor(with the alias name as as2_decrypting).
  • Mention the alias name in the public key alias.

In the MDN. There will be four options to be selected [ Synchronous, Asynchronous, Dynamic , None ]

If you select the Synchronous type [ In case you want the response when you sent the request]
You can request signing, with the specific Algorithm.

If you need to verify signature. You need to give the Private key alias. Which is the certificate that you will get from the sender adapter which can be found in the Keystore.

Paste the EDI payload in the content modifier as specified above.

ISA*01*0000000000*01*0000000000*ZZ*ABCDEFGHIJKLMNO*ZZ*123456789012345*101127*1719*U*00401*000003438*0*P*>
GS*PO*4405197800*999999999*20101127*1719*1421*X*004010VICS
ST*850*000000010

REF*DP*038
REF*PS*R

This is the integration flow for which the MDN Attachment need to be sent as we have selected asynchronous Communication.

  1. In the Connection tab specify a path for the as2 endpoint.
  2. Select the Authorization to be UserRole/Client_Certificate[In my case I selected User Role]
  3. You need to send the PFX file to the SENDER ADAPTER iflow tenant because you will be receiving the response asynchronously from the sender adapter.

Monitoring the Artifacts in Trace Mode

 

Creation of PFX Certificate

Creation of PFX Certificate contains these below steps:

  1. Go to the Integration flow instance [DEV]
  2. Create a certificate in the Instance.

         

3. After creating Certificate (From the Form tab) Copy the Certificate and Align them as shown in image and save the file as <filename>.cert

       

4. Copy the Key, align as shown in image, save the file as <filename>.key

 

       

5. Now use this website (or any other online websites for pfx generation)https://www.sslshopper.com/ssl-converter.html

 
  1. Upload the cert file and key file in this website with the proper pfx password (remember the password)
  2. Click on Create and download PFX file.

Stay tuned for the next part, where weâ€™ll get started with API proxies!

entry.title: SAP Master Data Integration (MDI): SAP S/4HANA Business Partner Replication using DRF Customizing
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog builds on our earlier post on SAP MDI Architecture and Deployment. Here, we explore end-to-end configuration for replicating Business Partner data from an SAP S/4HANA system to SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) using SOAP-based communication and DRF (Data Replication Framework).

Prerequisites

Ensure the following are in place:

  • SAP MDI service instance and service key created in SAP BTP Cockpit
  • DRF enabled in the S/4HANA system
  • Role-based access to SOAMANAGER
  • Active connectivity between SAP BTP and On-Premises via SAP Cloud Connector

DRF Configuration

  • In DRFIMG, create a Business System with BO Type and Communication System "Replication via Services" for the object "986" for Business Partner including Relationships.
  • Ensure the Business System ID matches the one used in the MDO configuration to avoid integration errors.
  • Assign Outbound Implementation "986_3 Outbound Implementation for BP/REL via Services", Assign Target System and Outbound Parameters under "Define Replication Models".
  • Repeat steps above for Key Mapping as 1376 if the integration scenario requires key mapping replication.

 WSDL Setup via SOAMANAGER

Download WSDLs

  • Download 6 WSDLs as per SAP Note 2987243

Customize and Upload
  • Now we have the below 6 WSDL Files:
    BusinessPartnerSUITEBulkReplicateRequest_Out
    BusinessPartnerSUITEBulkReplicateConfirmation_Out
    BusinessPartnerRelationshipSUITEBulkReplicateRequest_Out
    BusinessPartnerRelationshipSUITEBulkReplicateConfirmation_Out
    KeyMappingBulkReplicateRequest_Out
    KeyMappingBulkReplicateConfirmation_Out
  • Add the following elements at the end of each of the WSDL Files before the </wsdl:definitions> tag.
  • It is important to note that the below XML element contains a sample SAP Master Data Integration Endpoint.
    <wsdl:service name="...">
    <wsdl:port name="..." binding="...">
    <soap:address location="https://<uri>:443/businesspartner/v0/soap/BusinessPartnerRelationshipBulkReplicateRequestConfirmIn?tenantId=<identity_zone>" />
    </wsdl:port>
    </wsdl:service>
  • You need to replace this with your Master Data Integration details for all of them.
    The SAP Master Data Integration Endpoint is of the following pattern:<uri>:443/businesspartner/v0/soap/BusinessPartnerRelationshipBulkReplicateRequestConfirmIn?tenantId=<identity_zone>
    In the above pattern:
    URI is equal to the value of attribute â€œuriâ€ in your Master Data Integration instanceâ€™s service key
    identity_zone is equal to the value of attribute â€œidentity zoneâ€ in your Master Data Integration instanceâ€™s service key
    Example for 1 WSDL- https://one.mds.cfapps.sap.hana.ondemand.com:443/businesspartner/v0/soap/BusinessPartnerRelationshipBulkReplicateRequestConfirmIn?tenantId=mdibpconsumer1
  • Upload all 6 WSDLs in SOA Management

Publish WSDLs to Services Registry

  • Use Services Registry â†’ Publication of External WSDL
  • Assign appropriate internal names, bindings, and physical systems
  • Reuse the physical system object across all WSDLs after first creation

MDI System Access Profile

  • Go to Technical Administration â†’ Profiles
  • Create a new profile with:
    Auth: User ID/Password
    Transport: Secured communication
  • Link this profile to the provider system using the same Business System ID as DRF

Logon Data Management

  • Go to Service Administration â†’ Logon Data Management
  • Create credentials using:
    clientId as username
    clientSecret as password from the MDI service key

Local Integration Scenario Configuration

  • Go to Local Integration Scenario Configuration
  • Add these service groups:
    MDG_BS_SUPPLIERREPLICATEREQ
    MDG_BS_SUPPLIERREPLICATECONF
    KEY_MAP_REPLICATE_REQ
    KEY_MAP_REPLICATE_CONF

  • Assign IBC Reference to each from the MDI system
  • Link all service groups to the created Logon Data

Activate Logical Ports

  • Go to Service Administration â†’ Pending Tasks
  • Process all pending tasks
  • Validate port creation via Web Service Configuration

SOAP Endpoint Setup for MDI

  • Go to Web Service Configuration
  • For each of the 6 service definitions (e.g. BUSINESSPARTNERSUITEBULKREPLIC), create a service binding
  • Under â€œTransport Settingsâ€, copy the Calculated Access URL
  • Final endpoint:
    https://<host>:<port>/<calculated_access_url>
    Example: 
    https://ldciemt.wdf.sap.corp:44322/sap/bc/srt/xip/sap/businesspartnersuitebulkreplic/405/mdibpconsumer11/binding8

This URL is then used to configure the BPOUTBOUND destination in your BTP subaccount.

Conclusion

With this setup complete, your S/4HANA system is now capable of replicating Business Partner master data to SAP MDI in real-time via push or pull mechanisms. Youâ€™ve established secure communication, configured service groups, and integrated SOAP endpoints â€” ensuring a robust and scalable MDI architecture.
Please note the Blog is to connect S/4HANA on-prem/Private Cloud system to MDI, there can be more scenario where the MDI would be then connected to other systems. For such scenarios, configuration is required in Master Data Orchestration or Business Data Orchestration.

More Blogs:
SAP Master Data Integration (MDI): Architecture, D... - SAP Community

entry.title: Bridging the gap with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper
entry.content:
With the extended maintenance end date rapidly approaching for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition releases 1503, 1603, 1709 - 1909, it is time for impacted customers to start planning their next steps before entering customer-specific maintenance on January 1, 2026. â€¯

Mainstream maintenance, extended maintenance, and customer-specific maintenance are the three distinct maintenance phases applicable to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition under the SAP Maintenance Strategy.â€¯ 

During mainstream maintenance, full support (SAP Notes, Support packages, Support package stacks, Feature package stacks, etc) is offered for a SAP product until a successor product is available. Extended maintenance offers similar support but requires a specific maintenance contract. For RISE customers, extended maintenance for S/4HANA Cloud private edition is covered by the regular annual subscription fee and does not require a specific maintenance addendum. Once extended maintenance ends, systems enter customer-specific maintenance (CSM), a phase with limited and restricted support services. Entering CSM as a RISE customer means the support and Service Level Agreement currently provided by SAP Enterprise Cloud Services will no longer be available.

â€¯S/4HANA Maintenance Timelines â€¯ 

â€¯ 

To fully leverage the value of SAP, it's essential for customers to keep their S/4HANA release up to date - ensuring robust security, continuous innovation and optimal system performance. For this reason, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service has been released to support RISE with SAP customers who have not yet upgraded to the latest S/4HANA Cloud, private edition version and are at risk of falling into customer-specific maintenance.â€¯â€¯New customers who have not yet upgraded must upgrade before moving to RISE. Alternatively, they can move to RISE on their current S/4HANA release before entering customer-specific maintenance, as long as they also purchase the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service. Customer-specific maintenance is not supported for new RISE customers. Safekeeper services are only applicable to S/4HANA Cloud releases, not SAP ERP.  

 

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service is purchased as a single sales SKU and includes:â€¯ 

1) Upgrade Servicesâ€¯ 

A) SAP Cloud Application Services (CAS) for Release Version Upgradeâ€¯ 

ORâ€¯ 

B) SAP Cloud Application Services (CAS) for Regression Testingâ€¯â€¯ 

â€¯ 

2) Infrastructureâ€¯ 

An additional non-productive sandbox tier is provided by SAP to match the size of the existing production system up to 6TiB. â€¯ 

 

3) Maintenance-related servicesâ€¯ 

Your existing S/4HANA landscape entering customer-specific maintenance will continue to receive SAP Notes and corrections generally aligning with the scope of Extended Maintenance. It will mitigate the limitations of the customer-specific maintenance for the contracted period.â€¯â€¯ 

 

Letâ€™s look at two real-world scenarios.â€¯â€¯ 

Example #1 In-Place Upgrade from S/4HANA 1809 to S/4HANA 2023

I'm a RISE with SAP customer running SAP S/4HANA release 1809 which will enter customer-specific maintenance on January 1st, 2026.â€¯â€¯ I want to upgrade my existing systems to SAP S/4HANA 2023.â€¯â€¯ 

In this scenario, the customer purchases SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper at least 90 days prior to the safekeeper contract start date (Sept-30-2025) and opts for the upgrade service a) CAS for Release Version Upgrade. Customer has a production system RAM of 512GB.

As of January 1, 2026, the safekeeper service will be initiated. This includes:â€¯â€¯ 

  • â€¯ Deployment of the sandbox infrastructure (copy of existing production system running S/4HANA 1809)â€¯â€¯â€¯ 
  • Commencement of the CAS servicesâ€¯ 
  • SAP Notes and corrections on the existing S/4HANA 1809 landscape  

Following the infrastructure deployment, an upgrade planning workshop is scheduled with CAS delivery team to provide a detailed project plan. Any additional infrastructure for a parallel landscape (e.g. development/ testing) will need to be procured separately. SAP specialists guide, navigate, and support the upgrade/update process as a whole. On-going support is offered until the production go-live.â€¯â€¯ 

Example Brownfield Scenarioâ€¯ 

â€¯ 

Further readingâ€¯ 
CAS for Release Version Upgrade Scope Document: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/agreements/services/scope-documents.html?sort=latest_desc&search=release%20version%20upgradeâ€¯â€¯ 

How to upgrade blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/upgrade-your-sap-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-following-sap-activate/ba-p/13956251â€¯â€¯ 

 

#2 Greenfield/ Selective Data Transitionâ€¯ 

I'm a RISE with SAP customer running SAP S/4HANA release 1909 entering customer-specific maintenance on January 1, 2026.â€¯ I do not want to upgrade my existing systems, but instead, implement a new installation of systems on a more current release.â€¯â€¯ 

In this scenario, the suitable upgrade service is b) CAS for Regression Testing.â€¯â€¯ 

As of January 1, 2026, the safekeeper service will be initiated. This includes:â€¯â€¯ 

  • â€¯ Deployment of the sandbox infrastructure (empty greenfield system with the desired target release e.g. 2023)â€¯â€¯â€¯ 
  • Commencement of the CAS package for Regression Testingâ€¯ 
  • SAP Notes and corrections on the existing S/4HANA 1909 landscape  

Implementing a greenfield S/4HANA deployment typically involves replicating or redesigning previous business processes or adopting SAP best practices. These processes can be tested and validated in the new sandbox environment before implementing in other tiers. Customer will need to procure additional systems (DEV, QAS and PRD) based on the project plan.

Example Greenfield Scenarioâ€¯ 

â€¯ 

Further readingâ€¯ 

Regression Testing Service Scope Document: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/agreements/services/scope-documents.html?sort=latest_desc&search=SAP%20Cloud%20Application%20services%20for%20regression%20testingâ€¯â€¯ 

â€¯ 

As SAP S/4HANA 1503 and 1605 were built on an ECC solution stack, customers running these releases will require a system conversion to a more recent SAP S/4HANA release. In this scenario, CAS for Release Version Upgrade does not apply, and the CAS for Regression Testing will be offered.â€¯â€¯ 

â€¯ 

Contract Durationâ€¯ 

The minimum contract duration for Safekeeper is 12 months and the maximum is 27 months (or up to 48 months in case of releases 1503 & 1605). Customers are expected to have moved to a more current release within mainstream maintenance by the end of their contracted period. Extensions are available for customers who did not purchase the full term initially.â€¯ 

 

Add-onsâ€¯ 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper services are available for selected add-ons within the scope of RISE with SAP, as set forth in the list attached to the following SAP Note 3424346. This list will be expanded as new products are added, so it is recommended to check back frequently if you plan to use Safekeeper. â€¯ 

â€¯ 

Extract from the SAP S4HANA Cloud Safekeeper Add-on Listâ€¯ 

 

The single source of truth for Safekeeper availability is the SAP Product Availability Matrix at https://support.sap.com/pamâ€¯ 

Please note that add-ons having a longer mainstream maintenance date than Safekeeper availability for the specific release will not be included in the list attached to the SAP note. However, such add-ons will still be covered by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper services.â€¯â€¯ 

â€¯ 

Conclusionâ€¯ 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper has been introduced to support RISE with SAP customers in their transition to a more current SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition release. By providing structured upgrade or reimplementation paths, enabled by SAP Cloud Application Services, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper bridges the gap between the end of extended maintenance and the adoption of a current S/4HANA release, helping RISE customers maintain their support and SLAs from the SAP Enterprise Cloud Services organization.

â€¯ 

 

Acknowledgment to contributors/reviewers/advisors:

Aurelien Kuleczka, co-author, Cloud Architect & Advisor, Enterprise Cloud Services

Tara Gibney, co-author, Cloud Architect & Advisor, Enterprise Cloud Services

Saurabh Sharma, Cloud Architect & Advisor, Enterprise Cloud Services

Allan Hughes,  Cloud Architect & Advisor, Enterprise Cloud Services

Jurgen Pirotte, S/4HANA Centre of Excellence

Stefan Held, Cloud Architect & Advisor, Enterprise Cloud Services

Sara Dya, RISE with SAP Partner Business Development

entry.title: Staff your SAP Cloud ERP Enterprise Projects with the right Employees
entry.content:
Effective project and resource management is crucial for companies to deliver successful projects. Organizations running Enterprise Projects and/or Customer Projects in SAP Cloud ERP have the possibility to leverage SAP Project and Resource Management to optimize the project success. Resource Management is a process which spans normally over the complete lifetime of a project, starting with the initial finding and assignment of people, doing the continuous staffing forecasts and handling conflicts like substituting people. This blog provides an overview of how SAP Project and Resource Management facilitates these different staffing capabilities during the project life cycle of Enterprise Projects in SAP Cloud ERP.

Introduction:

Enterprise projects in SAP Cloud ERP   can be used to manage different kinds of projects in different industries. Examples are:

    • Overhead projects: for example, administrative projects or projects for research and development,
    • Investment projects: for example, projects to develop or maintain physical assets,
    • Projects with revenue: for example, engineer-to-order projects,
    • Statistical projects: can be used for certain reporting needs, without carry actual costs itself

Details about the different Project Types are documented in the following blog:
The two project control possibilities in SAP S/4HA... - SAP Community

 

Optimizing Resource Allocation:

Even in a simple project scenario, where an enterprise project merely serves as a cost collector without a formal project structure, managing resources is still required. Team members can log hours against the project, so optimizing resource allocation is crucial. To do this, you need clear visibility of available and skilled resources

Resource Management capability of SAP Project and Resource Management covers the following key aspects:

  • Transparency: Overview of projects people are working on and identification of conflicts
  • Reduce time to staff for Projects:
    • Staffing: Find available and skilled people and staff persons as requested and consider their availability
    • AI-assisted skill matching: overcome challenges like outdated employee profiles and reviewing many profiles manually
  • Increase staffing accuracy: Project workers can directly maintain their forecasts based on when they are needed for a project
  • Increase time-booking quality: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Timesheet worklist includes projects on which person is staffed
  • Single source of truth: the close integration between resource management information with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Project data provides synchronized data
  • SAP unified User Experience
  • Simple to adapt 

 

Basic scenarios and concepts:

SAP Project and Resource Management is a SaaS offering on SAP Business Technology Platform. Once the subscription is in place a scope item facilitates the setup.

Users can choose if resource management apps for business users should directly run in the SAP Cloud ERP Launchpad, e.g. Project Managers using the Project-related apps can also directly see the resource management apps they need.

 

Setup:

To proceed with the setup the following sources contain more details.
Administration Guide:
https://help.sap.com/docs/PPRM_OD/542f4545bc9d4ecd80bc3a0a6913a735/434f2ec669444cc98583a1c4eadca05a.html

The blog â€œSetup Resource Management Capability in SAP Project and Resource Managementâ€ provides a summary how to proceed by setting up the integration:
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/setup-resource-management-capability-in-sap-projects-and-resource/ba-p/13999829

 

Process:

Harmonizing staffing with project setup and milestone planning can reduce Backoffice efforts and allow people to focus on what is needed to deliver projects successfully instead of spending effort in maintaining consistent information across different sources.  

The process starts in SAP Cloud ERP when a Resource demand is created:

 


Screen shows the resource demand defined in the Enterprise Project

Once the Enterprise Project Integration is setup for SAP Cloud ERP â€œhuman resourceâ€ demands create the Resource Requests in Resource Management.

The process is explained along the most used apps in this blog.

1. Manage Resource Requests (Role: Project Manager)

Resource Request contains the need for a specific resource and is normally being refined by a user, e.g. Project Manager. During the refinement information about needed skills, scope description, requested resource organization are added. Once the request is complete the Project Manager can â€œpublishâ€ the request, so it becomes visible to the Resource Managers. No need to send additional information via email and capture the information directly where it is needed.


Screen shows the resource request which was published and includes â€œSAP Cloud ERPâ€ as a required skill

 

2. Staff Resource Requests (Role: Resource Manager)

Resource Managers review the request and start now with the search of candidates. Availability and Skill matching are performed and available candidates identified. Resource Manager can propose or directly staff one or multiple candidates:

  • Proposing a candidate, allows Project Manager to accept / decline candidates
  • Soft booking is not yet confirmed staffing and only visible in resource management, while Hard booking is a confirmed booking type and people will see staffing in the SAP Cloud ERP timesheet app.
  • Forward requests, in case no suitable candidates are identified a request can be forwarded to another organization

Learn more how the AI-Assisted Advanced Skill Matching facilitates the search of skilled candidates check:
Unlock Efficient Resource Management with AI in SA... - SAP Community


Screen shows the matching candidates list and the Advanced Skill Match for Lilian Blair â€“ Lilian is being assigned by using the â€œQuick Assignâ€ feature

 

3. Manage Resource Utilization (Role: Resource Manager)

Provides transparency how people are utilized, visualizes conflicts of over / under bookings and shows directly on which projects and roles people are working.

Resource Managers can also create, change and move assignments in order to resolve conflicts and adjust the planning.


Screen shows a list of filtered employees which includes Lilian Blair and her staffing for the Project Expert role

 

4. My Assignments (Role: Project Team Member)

Once employees are staffed and have the needed authorization, they can maintain a staffing forecast means they can adjust in which weeks they work how many hours on a project. This allows them to refine and balance between different project assignments and align their involvement along with the planned project milestones, considering planned absences etc.

The updated information is afterwards visible for Resource- and Project Managers to ensure everyone has the updated information.



Screen shows mobile view of Lilianâ€™s â€œMy Assignmentâ€ app.

Staffed hours and candidates will be visible in SAP Cloud ERP. The Enterprise Project demand will get directly information about the assigned people and hours. This helps to bring up staffing information in the employeeâ€™s timesheet worklist to simplify timesheet capturing and reduce the time to find the right project.

 

Summary:

Resources assignments and staffed hours are kept in synch between the SAP Cloud ERP and Resource Management, which ensures that all users have the same view on resource demands and what is being staffed.

SAP Project and Resource Management supports you by gaining transparency on your resource utilization situation with a fully integrated and embedded into the SAP User Experience scenario.

To learn more and to explore Resource Management in SAP Project and Resource Management you can find more information and access the free trial under:

https://www.sap.com/prm

 

Companies running Customer Projects in SAP Cloud ERP can also consult the following blog:
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/overcoming-challenges-in-staffing-customer-projects-with-sap-project-and/ba-p/13748436

Dear Utilities Community

I am delighted to announce that the July edition of the SAP Utilities newsletter is live!

 

Once again, we have exciting news to share about the utilities industry!

We find ourselves in an exciting phase of innovation. Read the update about our SAP Continuous Influence Session for SAP S/4HANA Utilities. As an SAP customer, you can submit improvement requests, vote on ideas from others, and collaborate with SAP experts to help develop forward-looking solutions.

The coming weeks are packed with events! First up is SAP for Utilities by ASUG happening from September 8-10 in Denver. Then we head to CHARGE Europe in Istanbul on October 13-14, 2025. Weâ€™re also pleased to showcase customer success stories from around the world. Iberdrola is integrating AI in its daily operations to accelerate the energy transition. Hinduja Renewables is scaling with SAP Cloud ERP, while TEAG is advancing digitalization and decentralization with RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud. entry.title: Re: Storage Location as MRP area
entry.content:
If the storage location is not there in PR, then, it could be due to the following reasons

  • If the sales order for the FG material doesnâ€™t pass the storage location correctly to the raw material demand, the system defaults to plant-level planning. This often happens when the BOM or routing doesnâ€™t specify the storage location for the component. So, if needed, check with PP team also on MRP related settings.
  • In MRP1, the MRP Area assignment must be active. In MRP4, check the Storage Location MRP Indicatorâ€”it should be set to 2 (Sloc-level planning). If this is missing, the system may revert to plant-level planning even during Sloc-level MRP runs.
  • If the special procurement key or source list doesnâ€™t specify a storage location, the PR will be created without oneâ€”even if MRP was run at the Sloc level.

entry.title: Re: Unable to see the log during Invoice cancellation
entry.content:
Hi,

It seems you are encountering an issue with the custom logic implemented in the BADI SD_BIL_FLEX_CANCELLATION Sales - Flexible Billing Document Cancellation for invoice cancellation based on the IRN status. The error message â€˜Invoice cannot be cancelled please cancel the IRN firstâ€™ is visible during debugging but not in the VF11 app, where you see a blank log screen.

You may try to add a message to log to help you better debugging. 

CLASS-METHODS log_message
IMPORTING
!iv_msgty TYPE symsgty
!iv_msgid TYPE symsgid
!iv_msgno TYPE symsgno
!iv_msgv1 TYPE any OPTIONAL
!iv_msgv2 TYPE any OPTIONAL
!iv_msgv3 TYPE any OPTIONAL
!iv_msgv4 TYPE any OPTIONAL.

METHOD log_message.
DATA: ls_message TYPE bapireturn.
ls_message-type = iv_msgty.
ls_message-id = iv_msgid.
ls_message-number = iv_msgno.
ls_message-message_v1 = iv_msgv1.
ls_message-message_v2 = iv_msgv2.
ls_message-message_v3 = iv_msgv3.
ls_message-message_v4 = iv_msgv4.
APPEND ls_message TO messages.
ENDMETHOD.

Best regards, Dequan Xu

entry.title: API to download attachments of Projects
entry.content:
Dear Team,

I am trying to download attachments of projects through API so I have enabled communication arrangement with scenario, SAP_COM_0308. But I don't understand how to use this API to get attachment. Can you please suggest us how to fulfill our requirement?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: API to download attachments of Projects
entry.content:
In the communication scenario Enterprise Project Integration (SAP_COM_0308), you can use the generic Attachments service (API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV) to manage attachments. Please follow below steps: 

1. Call GET method with operation GetAllOriginals to retrieve the metadata of the attachment associated with the project.

  • For enterprise project, use BusinessObjectTypeName = '/S4PPM/PRJ' and LinkedSAPObjectKey = '<UUID for project> or <UUID for WBS element>'
  • For professional services project, use BusinessObjectTypeName = '/CPD/EP' and LinkedSAPObjectKey = '<external ID for project>'
  • For professional services project element, use BusinessObjectTypeName = '/CPD/PFP' and LinkedSAPObjectKey = '<external ID for work package>'

Sample request URL for professional services work package:
GET <host>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV/GetAllOriginals?BusinessObjectTypeName='/CPD/PFP'&LinkedSAPObjectKey='<external ID for work package> '

The following properties can be found in response body:
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocType>xxx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocType>
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber>xxxxxxxxx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber>
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion>xx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion>
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocPart>xxx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocPart>
<d:LogicalDocument>xxxxxxxxx</d:LogicalDocument>
<d:ArchiveDocumentID>xxxxxxxxx</d:ArchiveDocumentID>
<d:LinkedSAPObjectKey>xxxxxxxxx</d:LinkedSAPObjectKey>
<d:BusinessObjectTypeName>xxxxxxxxx</d:BusinessObjectTypeName>

2. Use the properties retrieved from step 1 to call GET method with entity AttachmentContentSet to download the attachment content.

Sample request URL:
GET <host>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV/AttachmentContentSet(DocumentInfoRecordDocType='xxx',DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber='xxxxxxxxx',DocumentInfoRecordDocPart='xxx',DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion='xx',LogicalDocument='xxxxxxxxx',ArchiveDocumentID='xxxxxxxxx',LinkedSAPObjectKey='xxxxxxxxx',BusinessObjectTypeName='xxxxx')/$value

entry.title: Re: The E in Event-Driven Architecture: Introducing SAPâ€™s new Event-Add for ERP
entry.content:
Hi @Cocquerel ,

currently the differences are in respect to connectivity (via AEM) and to pricing. In future the intention is to add features that would be unique to the Event Add-On.

In respect to the details of the pricing the SAP Discovery Center is the place. I assume you have looked up the number there, and this is what I would recommend. It seems in the right range.

Let me try to help you with a few statements though that will make it easier to put the pricing in context:

  • You do pay for activated AEM brokers - you do activate a broker for use with the add-on in AEM.
  • You can connect several backends with add-ons installed to an AEM broker (e.g. an ECC and an S/4HANA against a single broker)
  • There is no differentiation between productive, test or dev brokers. So dev or test brokers are not free of charge. As said, it is the activations on AEM brokers that count, not the number of installed add-ons.
  • The pricing is tiered as you can see in Discovery Center. 

Hope this helps for now. I understand that we need to provide reference architectures and pricing examples as part of this blog series.

Best,

Karsten

entry.title: Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters â€“ A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration
entry.content:
In the era of APIs, hybrid landscapes, and cloud-native development, it's easy to assume that methodologies like SAP ISA-M (Integration Solution Advisory Methodology) are outdated. But the truth is: ISA-M is more relevant than ever. It remains a strategic compass for defining and implementing integration architectures that are sustainable, business-aligned, and tool-agnostic.

 

ðŸ” What is SAP ISA-M?

SAP ISA-M is a structured methodology that helps enterprises define their integration strategy, classify integration use cases, and select the right technologies and governance models. It supports decision-making across cloud, hybrid, and on-premise landscapes â€“ regardless of whether youâ€™re using SAP Integration Suite, SAP Advanced Event Mesh, or third-party platforms.

ðŸ”‘ Why ISA-M Still Matters Today

  1. Strategic Guidance for Cloud Transformation

ISA-M is widely used during S/4HANA and RISE with SAP transformations to assess legacy middleware (e.g., PI/PO) and design modern, API- and event-driven target architectures.

  1. Technology-Agnostic by Design

ISA-M is not tied to specific products. It provides a framework for integration strategy, which remains valid even as tools evolve â€“ from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite and beyond.

  1. Use Case-Driven Approach

By analyzing integration needs across five integration styles (e.g., process integration, data integration, event-driven integration), ISA-M helps teams design purposeful and scalable architectures.

  1. Connecting Business and IT

The methodology fosters collaboration between business owners, architects, and integration teams â€“ ensuring that integration becomes a business enabler, not just a technical necessity.

 

Where ISA-M is Used Today

âœ… Cloud Transformations & RISE with SAP

âœ… Modernization of Legacy Interfaces

âœ… Enablement & Governance Models

It outlines the phases in a modernization journeyâ€”Review, Scope and Define Use Casesâ€”and shows how to transition towards a future-ready, hybrid integration platform.

  • Assess Integration Strategy
  • Review Existing Integration Architecture
  • Scope and Define Best Practices and Target Architecture
  • Give power to the people

 

ðŸš€ Outlook: Whatâ€™s Next for ISA-M?

ðŸ”§ 1. ISA-M in INTAS â€“ SAP Integration Assessment Service

SAPâ€™s INTAS (Integration Assessment Service) is a structured offering to help customers evaluate and modernize their integration landscape. ISA-M provides the core methodology behind this service:

  • Assessment of legacy and custom interfaces
  • Mapping use cases to modern SAP Integration Suite capabilities
  • Tailored modernization roadmap aligned to Clean Core principles

With INTAS, organizations benefit from a guided modernization plan that is both strategic and executable.

I will give you some more insights in on of our upcoming Integration Modernization expert sessions: https://events.sap.com/expertsession-isam/en_us/home.html

ðŸ”— 2. ISA-M and the SAP Integrated Toolchain

The SAP Integrated Toolchain for Modernization Projects combines multiple SAP tools and services, such as:

  • SAP Cloud ALM
  • SAP Signavio
  • SAP LeanIX
  • SAP WalkMe
  • SAP BTP ( with our focus on Integration Suite)

We us ISA-M acts as a strategic layer below the toolchain, ensuring that all activities â€“ from modeling to implementation â€“ follow a consistent integration strategy. For example:

  • LeanIX is the central tool for your overall Enterprise Architecture  â†’ ISA-M will help to control technologies and applications along the concept and to establish a government model
  • Signavio is used to model business processes â†’ ISA-M helps derive integration patterns
  • SAP Integration Suite itself can be used to integrate the toolchain (itself) â†’ ISA-M ensures style and governance fit, e.g. usage of SAP Advanced Event Mesh in combination with LeanIX Webhooks.

ISA-M connects the dots, providing strategic continuity across the entire toolchain.

We are currently working out an Integration Modernization expert which will give the required insights how you can implement it. Stay tune and follow our journey here https://events.sap.com/eur-sap-integration-modernization-expert-sessions/en_us/home.html

You would like to practice (e.g. with Integration content)? Just let me know.

ðŸ§¼  3. ISA-M and Clean Core

Clean Core is one of the key guiding principles in SAPâ€™s modernization strategy. But a Clean Core isnâ€™t just about avoiding modifications â€“ itâ€™s about separating business logic from system logic and creating modular, scalable architectures.

Hereâ€™s how ISA-M supports a Clean Core approach:

  • Recommends using APIs, events, and standardized integration styles
  • Avoids hard-coded dependencies between systems
  • Encourages centralized governance and reuse of services

By following ISA-M, companies are not just modernizing their interfaces â€“ they are actively cleaning their core.

 We hosted a first session how ISA-M can help you to ensure a clean-core approach Find the recording here: https://dam.sap.com/mac/app/e/video/embed/vAemLss?ltr=a&rc=10&doi=SAP1206809&includeSapBrandedWraper=true&includeRelatedAssets=true

 

âœ… Final Thoughts

Integration is no longer just a technical challenge â€“ itâ€™s a strategic business discipline. And while the tools and technologies evolve, the need for a methodical, business-aligned integration strategy remains constant.

Thatâ€™s why ISA-M continues to be a critical success factor for integration modernization, clean core transformation, and cloud-centric architectures.

Whether you're just starting your transformation journey or reviewing an existing landscape, ISA-M gives you the structure, language, and clarity to do it right.

ðŸ‘‰ Explore more:

  • ISA-M GitHub Repository
  • ISA-M Mission in SAP Discovery Center

 You need support? Send us a mail SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>

entry.title: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, How to declare VAT on cash basis?
entry.content:
Dear
I wondered if somebody from your team could help us on an S4HANA public cloud finance question by pointing us in the right direction.

 

Our customer as 3 subsidiaries in Germany. They make VAT declaration on accrual.

Only 1 entity in Germany wants to make VAT declaration on cash.

 

Is this possible?

 

We are looking for a functionality which would generate VAT report in Germany based on payments. It should be called VAT on cash basis method, when you report your tax only in case it was already paid.

 

So the obligation to report VAT is further determined by the fact we have a payment in system related to invoice or other transaction where tax was posted.

 

It is an opposite to accrual VAT method, where tax must be reported immediately upon invoice posting regardless of its payment.

Thank you in advance.
Best regards,

- Daniel

entry.title: ðŸš€ Mastering SAP Cloud ALM â€“ Change Management with a Demo Tenant: Your Step-by-Step Getting Started
entry.content:
SAP Cloud ALM (Application Lifecycle Management) is a modern, cloud-native platform developed by SAP to support the entire application lifecycleâ€”from initial implementation and project planning to operations and continuous improvement. Itâ€™s designed for both cloud and hybrid environments, empowering businesses to gain visibility, control, and agility in managing their SAP landscapes.

In this comprehensive walkthrough, weâ€™ll guide you through the practical setup and usage of SAP Cloud ALM using a demo tenant. Whether youâ€™re an SAP Basis consultant, implementation lead, or project manager, this tutorial is tailored to help you understand core elements like Implementation Projects, System Groups, Features, Transport Management, and Deployment Planning.

https://support.sap.com/en/alm/demo-systems/cloud-alm-demo-system.html?anchorId=section_1043771746

 

 

 

ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ’» For this demo, weâ€™ll be using the user Adam in the Cloud ALM tenant.

 

 

 

ðŸ§­ Step 1: Navigating to the Implementation App

To begin, access the â€œImplementationâ€ tab from the main SAP Cloud ALM dashboard.

 

 

 

ðŸ”— Navigate to: Implementation â†’ Projects and Setup

 

 

ðŸ› ï¸ Step 2: Create and Configure Your Implementation Project

ðŸ‘‰ In the â€œProjects and Setupâ€ section, click on â€œCreate Projectâ€.
Provide a project name, a brief description, and select the appropriate product (e.g., SAP S/4HANA).

This setup enables structured tracking of implementation activities and aligns your technical tasks with business goals.

 

 

 

 

ðŸ§© Step 3: Assign System Landscapes Using System Groups

âž¡ï¸ Go to the System Groups section.
ðŸ“Œ Enter a name for your group and select the relevant SAP product (e.g., SAP S/4HANA).
Assign each system (Development, Quality, and Production) to its respective role.

 

 

 

 

 

ðŸ’¡ System Groups help ensure a smooth flow of transports across your SAP landscape by logically organizing system roles.

ðŸ“¦ Step 4: Define a Deployment Plan

Navigate to the Deployment Plan area.

ðŸ—‚ Create a new deployment plan, associate it with your System Group, and specify relevant Release Versions.
This configuration allows you to coordinate when and how different features will be delivered across environments.

 

 

âœ”ï¸ Once done, assign this plan to your implementation project.

 

 

ðŸŒŸ Step 5: Manage Features and Functional Enhancements

Open the Features tab and click â€œCreate Feature.â€

 

 

A Feature in Cloud ALM is a unit of work or change. You can:

  • ðŸ”— Link it to a Requirement (business need).

 

  • ðŸ“¦ Attach a Release to group multiple features into one go-live bundle.

 

  • ðŸ§­ Align it with the Deployment Plan for controlled rollout.

ðŸ“Œ Features track the end-to-end journey of a changeâ€”from planning to productive use.

ðŸ“¤ Step 6: Assign or Create Transports for the Feature

Inside the feature, scroll to the Transports create section.

ðŸ›  Click â€œCreate Transportâ€ to initiate a transport request.

 

 

 

 

Once assigned, click â€œStart Implementationâ€ to activate development.

 

 


The feature status updates to â€œIn Implementation.â€

ðŸ” Step 7: Release Transport Tasks and Generate TOCs

When development is complete, release the individual tasks within the transport in the Development system.

 

ðŸŒ€ Return to the Cloud ALM interface and click the â€œCopyâ€ button in the Transports section to create a Transport of Copies (TOC).

 

 

âœ… TOCs allow early testing of changes in the Quality system without releasing the main transport prematurely.

  • A grey icon indicates TOC creation is in progress.

 

 

  • Once successful, the icon turns green, and the TOC is auto-scheduled for import to Quality.

 

ðŸ§ª Step 8: Initiate Testing in Quality System

After successful import of the TOC into Quality:

ðŸ§ª Click â€œHandover to Testâ€ within the feature.
The status will change to â€œIn Testingâ€, signaling readiness for validation.

 

 

 

ðŸš€ Step 9: Release and Deploy the Main Transport

Once changes are validated:

  1. Click â€œReleaseâ€ to release the main TR from Development.

 

 

 

  1. Click â€œDeployâ€ to move the main TR into the Quality system.

 

ðŸ”„ This approach ensures compliance with change management best practices.

ðŸ Step 10: Approve and Move to Production

After testing in Quality is complete:

  1. Update the feature status to â€œApprove for Production.â€
  2.  

 

 

  1. It will now reflect as â€œReady for Production.â€

 

  1. Click â€œDeployâ€ again to move the main transport into the Production system.

 

ðŸ“‹ Use the History tab to review changes, user activity, and timestamps for full traceability.

 

 

âœ… Conclusion

SAP Cloud ALM, when used via the demo tenant, provides a powerful sandbox environment to understand how lifecycle operations, project structures, and transport workflows are orchestrated in SAP.

By following this structured approach, you gain practical experience in:

  • Creating projects and system landscapes
  • Managing features and requirements
  • Orchestrating transport flows from Development to Production
  • Ensuring auditability and traceability with built-in monitoring

ðŸŽ¯ Whether you're preparing for a live customer implementation or upskilling on SAP Cloud ALM, this guide gives you a clear head start.

entry.title: Re: When adding AP Invoice from draft mode, system is sho...
entry.content:
Hi,

Check whether the account is defined at the following path:

Administration -> Setup -> Inventory -> Locations -> Select the location used for the transaction -> Accounting Data-> Excise tab -> 'Capital Goods On Hold Account'.

Kr,

Jitin

entry.title: Re: Ariba API (json / cXML)
entry.content:
@simon_all4cloud41 :
- JSON: this is only for requesting an existing purchase order with all the information

- cXML: provides a lot more information and possibilities, e.g. rejecting a purchase order and and and.

So, it depends on your use cases (sorry for a "it depends answer" ;-))

entry.title: Re: historial stocks and production orders are not visibl...
entry.content:
Go to transaction CFC2 in your ECC system.
Debug setting "R Debugging on and T/QRFCs are only recorded" can be useful for testing. Maintain the Debug setting "R" temporary during a test phase.
As soon as you have finished the tests, use "Debugging off" and change the Debug setting to " " (blank space) as shown in the options menu for this field.

entry.title: Re: Performance DB SELECT * FOR ALL statement can be joined with SELECT statement at ... line ...
entry.content:
I faced similar issue while using FOR ALL ENTRIES statement. I was able to remove the CHECK Message by adding SORT statement after the SELECT statement.

SELECT old_vendor FROM zxxx_vendor_xxx INTO TABLE gt_pur_lfa1 
FOR ALL ENTRIES IN gt_ekorg WHERE old_vendor = gt_ekorg-lifnr.
IF sy-subrc = 0.
  SORT gt_pur_lfa1 BY old_vendor.
ENDIF.

entry.title: Re: Process modelling in SAP Signavio by importing proces...
entry.content:
Hi Gokul,
thanks for reaching out! SAP Signavio Process Manager offers BPMN import capabilities based on the BPMN 2.0 XML standard via UI or API. You can import BPMN files from external solutions if the export matches the BPMN notation:

  • SAP Help documentation for Importing a BPMN 2.0 XML
  • API
    • SAP Business Accelerator Hub
    • API Guide

Best regards
Manuel
